author: Simon Horsford
title: Travel programmes on TV
text:
Arts and Culture Travel programmes on TV Travel-related programmes this week include Ainsley Harriott testing street food in Fes and a documentary on Virgin Atlantic Fes, visited by Ainsley Harriott this week, is regarded as Morocco's cultural capital Photo: Fotolia/AP 
Friday July 3 
Gino's Italian Escape: A Taste of the Sun (ITV1, 8.00pm) 
Chef Gino D'Acampo sets off on another tour of his home country, this time exploring the north of Italy. He examines the food that has shaped the city of Florence, beginning by tackling the bistecca alla Fiorentina - a thick and juicy steak - before preparing sliced T-bone with a colourful courgette ribbon and goat's cheese salad. He then heads to the town of Prato, sampling a pastry chef's speciality brioche buns with an aromatic, creamy filling, and conjuring up his own dessert of apple poached in red wine with amaretti biscuit cream. Repeat. 
Sunday July 5 
Countryfile (BBC One, 7.00m) 
Matt Baker looks for basking sharks off the Cornish coast and scours the shoreline for shark egg cases. Ellie Harrison visits a project to map the entire UK coastline and learns about stinging nettles. John Craven reports on links between Cornish food producers and the Eden project. 
The Eden Project in Cornwall Photo: Fotolia/AP 
China From Above (National Geographic, 7.00pm) 
Stunning footage taking in how China works, eats, travels and plays and how the country has been transformed over the past three decades. 
Ainsley Harriott's Street Food (More4, 8.00pm) 
Ainsley Harriott arrives in the city of Fes in Morocco, as the residents prepare to celebrate Eid. He samples broad bean and garlic soup and chermoula with carrot and chickpea salad, and prepares pastilla pie with glazed nuts and fruits, spiced chicken kebabs and a tagine with rose-scented couscous 
Monday July 6 
Great British Railway Journeys Goes to Ireland (BBC Four, 7.30pm) 
Michael Portillo travels from Charleville, Co Cork, to the city of Waterford, along the way finding out about the ancient art of making butter, attempting to learn the basics of Ireland's oldest game, and riding on the Duke of Devonshire's Victorian railway. The series also runs on Tuesday and Wednesday. Repeat. 
Tuesday July 7 
Virgin Atlantic is the subject of a programme on ITV this week Photo: Getty 
Virgin Atlantic (ITV1, 9.00pm) 
Following the BBCâ€™s documentary on British Airways last year, ITV now gets in on the act by going behind the scenes at Virgin Atlantic during its 30th year. In this first episode, the employees at Virgin Atlantic's Crawley base are featured as they prepare for the company's landmark birthday event. Cameras also follow 58-year-old grandmother Katrine, who is hoping she has what it takes to become a new member of the cabin crew after working for many years in the ticket office. The film takes in designer Nik as he chooses the fittings for a new Boeing Dreamliner. 
Thursday July 9 
Our Holiday Coast (BBC Two, 9.00pm) 
The desire to escape the daily grind and head off on holiday is something many people crave - but why do so many still make a beeline for the beach? Nick Crane and the rest of the Coast team embark on a quest to find out. He begins by following a centuries-old tourist trail to Margate, revealing that the beach has a biological effect on people's stress levels. Miranda Krestovnikoff experiences a camping safari on Shell Island in north Wales and Ruth Goodman finds out about an explosive episode of pre-war politics that put sleepy St Leonards on the front pages
